questions.question: What is the most common site for a thyroglossal cyst?

options.C: At the level of the hyoid

questions.question: A 25-year-old patient presented with neck swelling which moves with deglutition as shownbelow. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: A thyroglossal cyst is the only midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition. This is becausethe thyroid gland is fixed to the hyoid.Thyroglossal duct cyst:It is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood often noticed afteran upper respiratory infection. It represents the persistence of the track of the thyroid gland andcan be found adjacent to the midline. The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the baseof the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. At the time of descent, the hyoid bone has notbeen formed and the track of the thyroid gland is variable, passing in front, through, or behind theeventual position of the hyoid body.TongueForamencaecumThyroglossalductHyoidThyrohyoidmembraneCricoidcartilageThyroid-glandSites of Thyroglossal CystOMARROWFloorof mouthBeneathforamencaecumSuprahyoidInfrahyoidThyroidcartilageClinical features of thyroglossal cyst:•Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. This indicatesattachment to the hyoid bone.•Swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), nontender, mobile, often transilluminant..Thyroid fossa is empty, if there is no thyroid in the normal location.Complications of thyroglossal cyst:• The most common complication is infection.• Thyroglossal fistula is an acquired condition that either follows infection of the cyst which burstsopen or due to inadequate removal of the cyst.• 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant of which the most common typeof cancer is papillary (85%).285Neck swellings that move with deglutition are:• Thyroid swellings•Subhyoid bursitis• Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid boneHowever, only the thyroglossal cyst moves with tongue protrusion. This is because the ductextends from the foramen caecum of the tongue to the isthmus of the gland.Sistrunk's operation is performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves theexcision of the whole thyroglossal tract, involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone,and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramencaecum along with the core of tissue on either side.

questions.question: 275A child with a midline swelling on the neck is being prepared for a Sistrunk procedure. Alongwith en bloc cystectomy, which of the following structures will be resected?

options.A: Thyroglossal tract and part of thyroid
options.B: Central hyoid bone and thyroglossal tract
options.D: Thyroglossal tract and associated cervical lymph nodes

questions.explanation: Sistrunk operation involves en bloc cystectomy with excision of the entire thyroglossal tract till thebase of the tongue along with the central hyoid bone.It is the procedure of choice for the surgical management of thyroglossal duct cysts. It is done toprevent recurrence and malignant transformation.The most common malignancy in thyroglossal cysts is papillary thyroid carcinoma. In such acase, Sistrunk operation with total thyroidectomy is considered.

questions.question: A patient with a nodule of the neck presents to the surgery OPD. A junior resident performsthe following method to palpate it. Identify the procedure shown in the video below.
questions.explanation: The video depicts Lahey's method of palpation of the left lobe of the thyroid gland.In Lahey's method, for palpating the left lobe, the examiner initially pushes the right lobe mediallywith the left hand, and then using the right hand, the border and consistency of the left lobe ispalpated.Other options:Option B: In Crile's method the patient is asked to swallow, while the examiner palpates the glandwith the thumb. This gives a clear indication regarding the slight enlargement of the thyroid glandor small nodules.286OMARROWOption C: Kocher's method is done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on thetrachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.Option D: Pemberton's sign (not method), is engorgement of neck veins when the patient is askedto raise their hands above the head and the arms should touch the ears. It is seen in patients withretrosternal goiter.

questions.question: A patient with a solitary, 2x3 cm, nodular thyroid swelling came to your clinic with a recentreport that showed elevated T4 and normal TSH levels. What is the next best step inmanagement?
questions.explanation: Ultrasonography is the next best step in the evaluation of a euthyroid (normal TSH) patient with asolitary thyroid nodule. USG is a non-invasive and inexpensive way to stratify the risk of thenodule into benign or malignant tissue.Benign nodules are easily compressible and can be seen to deform by applying pressure with theprobe while performing USG. Malignant nodules tend to be hard and firm.Ultrasound findings of a nodule that are considered suspicious of malignancy include:•Microcalcifications• Hypervascularity• Infiltrative margins• Hypoechoic compared with surrounding parenchyma287Approach to thyroid nodulesClinical historyRisk factorsPhysical examinationEuthyroid/ HypothyroidNormal/Elevated TSHUSG - NeckTSHNo nodule/BenignNo furtherinvestigationARSonographic impressionVery LowSuspicionLowSuspicionHyperthyroidColdLow TSHDOMTC SCanHotI-131orSurgeryHigh/IntermediateSuspicionSize = 2 cmSize 1.5 cmSize1 cmFNACIf the lesion does not meet the criteria for FNAC.serial monitoring with USG is done.OMARROW

questions.question: A 22-year-old student with a nodular thyroid swelling undergoes a radionuclide scan. What isthe risk of malignancy of the pathology given below?
questions.explanation: The pathology on the scan shows decreased iodine uptake by a cold thyroid nodule. It isassociated with around 20% risk of malignancy.A thyroid scan is used in patients with hyperthyroidism with low or normal TSH.Thyroid scan Cold vs. Hot noduleCold NoduleHot NoduleOMARROWHot nodules indicate increased function of the gland and are rarely malignant. They are managedwith either I131 or surgery. The risk of malignancy is higher with "cold" lesions (15-20%) ascompared to "warm" lesions (<5%).Cold nodules need to be further evaluated using USG as they pose a higher risk of malignancy.289Approach to thyroid nodulesClinical historyRisk factorsPhysical examinationEuthyroid/ HypothyroidNormal/Elevated TSHUSG - NeckTSHNo nodule/BenignNo furtherinvestigationARSonographic impressionVery LowSuspicionLowSuspicionHyperthyroidColdLow TSHDOMTC SCanHotI-131orSurgeryHigh/IntermediateSuspicionSize = 2 cmSize 1.5 cmSize1 cmFNACIf the lesion does not meet the criteria for FNAC.serial monitoring with USG is done.OMARROW

questions.question: A patient presents with a painless swelling of the neck. The histology of the tissue is as givenin the image below. What is the diagnosis?278
questions.explanation: The slide shows the histopathology of Hashimoto thyroiditis, with:• Follicular destruction• Reduced colloid with increased interstitial connective tissue•Small lymphocyte and plasma cell infiltration• A well-developed germinal centre may be seen• Hurthle (Askanazy) cells that have abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm lining the folliclesHashimoto's thyroiditisGerminalcentreReducedcolloidin follicle291HurthlecellsHashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. Itis also known as struma lymphomatosa or lymphocytic thyroiditis. It is an autoimmune diseasethat results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual & progressive thyroid failure.Clinical features:• Most prevalent between 45-65 years of age• More common in females• Painless enlargement of the thyroid• Hashitoxicosis: When the auto-antibodies attack and damage the follicles, there is a suddenrelease of thyroid hormones from these follicles. This leads to a transient phase of thyrotoxicosis.Hypothyroidism: Since the follicles are damaged and cannot form the hormones anymore, thesepatients tend to be in a state of hypothyroidism.•Diagnosis:•T3 and T4 are low• TSH is raised.• Autoantibodies against:•Thyroid receptors• Thyroid peroxidase (TPO)• ThyroglobulinThese patients are managed with thyroid hormone replacement therapy.In patients with long-standing goiter, there is a risk of compressive features and the developmentof thyroid lymphoma. Such cases can be treated with total thyroidectomy. It may also predisposeto papillary thyroid carcinoma.Other options:Option A: Histological features of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid include polygonal tospindle-shaped cells in the form of nests, trabeculae or follicles. Small, round anaplastic cells maybe found in some cases and amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin polypeptides are present inthe stroma.The given slide below shows medullary carcinoma of thyroid:292Option C: Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder characterized by hyperthyroidism due tocirculating autoantibodies. The thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins bind to the TSH receptors,causing overgrowth of the thyroid gland and increased thyroid hormone synthesis. Histologically,there is acinar cell hypertrophy and hyperplasia with the absence of normal colloid in the tallcolumnar epithelium (normally the epithelium is flat with colloid). Lymphoid infiltrates,consisting predominantly of T cells, along with scattered B cells and mature plasma cells, arepresent throughout the interstitium. Germinal centers are common.The given slide below shows Grave's disease:

questions.question: A middle-aged female patient presented with malaise, fever, and painful neck swelling. Shehad recently recovered from an episode of upper respiratory tract infection. Lab reports showslightly elevated T4 and ESR was 100 mm/hr. What is the most appropriate managementoption for this patient?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of De Quervain's thyroiditis for which NSAIDs is thetreatment of choice. In this condition, T3, T4 and thyroglobulin may be raised due to the release293of preformed hormones from the destructed follicles.De Quervain's thyroiditis (subacute or viral thyroiditis) is a granulomatous enlargement of thethyroid gland, usually following a viral infection. It is an inflammatory condition and not aninfection as the thyroid gland is inherently resistant to infection due to its extensive blood andlymphatic supply, high iodide content, and fibrous capsule.It predominantly occurs in women between the ages of 30-40 years. The condition is self-limiting,and management is symptomatic i.e. aspirin and other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs areused for pain relief, but steroids may be indicated in more severe cases.Note: Acute suppurative thyroiditis mimics De Quervain's thyroiditis in that it is often precededby a pyogenic upper respiratory tract infection or otitis media. However, acute suppurativethyroiditis is more common in children.

questions.question: A 45-year-old lady, with a painless neck swelling, presented with palpitations and weight loss.Thyroid function tests revealed elevated T3 and T4, low TSH, and negative TSH-R Ab. Iodinescan showed multiple thyroid nodules with increased iodine uptake. Initial anti-thyroidtreatment was given. What is the next step of management?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of toxic multinodular goitre. The next step ofmanagement once a euthyroid state is achieved is a near-total thyroidectomy.Toxic nodular goiters are often large, uncomfortable, and are prone to recurrence. In a developingcountry like India, a near-total thyroidectomy eliminates the risk of recurrence and simplifiesfollow-up. However, it causes immediate thyroid failure and necessitates lifelong thyroxinereplacement.Option A: Toxic multinodular goitres may show a decreased response to antithyroid drugs or mayeven enlarge further. Therefore, surgical management is recommended.Option B: Sub-total thyroidectomy has chances of recurrence and hence cannot be a definitivetherapy.Option C: Large goiters show decreased response to radioactive iodine and the chances ofrecurrence are also high.

questions.question: What will be the most likely associated condition with increased TSH and low T4 levels?
questions.explanation: Increased TSH and low T4 levels are seen in primary hypothyroidism. Hashimoto's thyroiditis isthe only cause of primary hypothyroidism in the given options.Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroidgland and gradual & progressive thyroid failure. It is the most common cause of primaryhypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. They also have autoantibodies against thyroidreceptors, thyroid peroxidase and thyroglobulin.Other options:Option A: Hypoparathyroidism is generally not associated with hypothyroidism, except in certaincongenital multisystem disorders such as DiGeorge's syndrome.Option C: Grave's disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. It is an autoimmunedisorder caused due to autoantibodies against the TSH receptor. There will be elevated T3 and T4294levels with low TSH levels.Option B: A TSH-producing pituitary adenoma can have increased TSH levels, but there will beelevated T3, T4 levels as well.

questions.question: A 50-year-old hypothyroid female patient presents with a painless, hard anterior neck mass,which progresses over weeks to years associated with dysphagia. Physical examination revealsa hard, "woody" thyroid gland with fixation to the surrounding tissues. Which of the followinginvestigations will confirm the provisional diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Riedel's thyroiditis, which is confirmed by an openthyroid biopsy.FNAC is inadequate due to the firm and fibrous nature of the gland.Riedel's thyroiditis is invasive autoimmune fibrous thyroiditis where thyroid gland tissue isreplaced by fibrous tissue. It is an IgG4-related systemic disease characterized by:• Elevated serum IgG4 levels• Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate•Abundance of IgG4 bearing plasma cellsIt is associated with other focal sclerosing syndromes including mediastinal, retroperitoneal,periorbital, retro-orbital fibrosis, and sclerosing cholangitis.Clinical features:•Occurs predominantly in women between 30-60 yearsPainless, hard anterior neck mass•Progresses over weeks to years to produce symptoms of compression:• Dysphagia•• Dyspnea•⚫ Choking• Hoarseness•Symptoms of hypothyroidism and hypoparathyroidism as the gland is replaced by fibrous tissue• Physical examination reveals a hard, "woody" thyroid gland with fixation to surrounding tissuesTreatment includes surgery, high-dose steroids, tamoxifen, and thyroxine replacement.

questions.question: The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via:
questions.explanation: The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck and the most commontype of goitre approached is the secondary retrosternal goiter.A goiter is considered to be retrosternal if at least 50% of the thyroid tissue is locatedintrathoracically. They can be primary or secondary.Retrosternal goiter presents with dyspnoea, stridor, and dilated neck veins. Pemberton's sign(venous congestion of the neck on the raising of hands above the head) is seen.295Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the neck is performed to assess the locationof the thyroid. The definitive treatment is surgical excision of the ectopic thyroid.Other options:Option B & C: Median sternotomy (via chest) is indicated in:•Primary mediastinal goiter•Malignant retrosternal goiter•Very large retrosternal goiter• Recurrence in the mediastinumOccurrencPrimary retrosternal goiter1%eOriginBlood supplyArise fromectopic thyroid tissuein the chestNo connectionwith the thyroid tissue in theneckIntrathoracicblood vesselsSecondaryretrosternal goiterMajorityof retrosternal goiterArise from thedownward extension of cervical thyroid tissuealong the fascial planes of the neckSuperior and inferior thyroidarteries

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about retrosternal goitre?

options.A: Operated in all patients regardless of symptoms
options.B: Sternal incision is always required to operate
options.C: It receives blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery
options.D: Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by a neck incision

questions.explanation: Most of the retrosternal goiters can be removed by neck incision (transcervical approach).Retrosternal goitre is defined as having >50% of the goiter below the suprasternal notch. It canbe either primary or secondary.•Primary: rare and arises from ectopic thyroid tissue in the mediastinum; receives blood supplyfrom intrathoracic blood vessels. It is not related to thyroid tissue in the neck.•Secondary: they are the most common type; an extension of enlarged thyroid from the neck,usually arising from the lower pole of nodular goitre. It receives its blood supply from superiorand inferior thyroid vessels.The majority of patients are asymptomatic or have minimal symptoms. If the gland enlargeswithin the thoracic inlet, the pressure may lead to dysphagia, tracheal compression, andeventually airway symptoms. Pemberton sign can be positive (facial flushing and dilatation ofcervical veins upon raising the arms above the head).CECT neck and thorax is the investigation of choice.Over 95% of retrosternal goiters can be removed via a transcervical incision since they are anextension from thyroid tissue in the neck.Other options:Option A: Surgical removal of the retrosternal goiter is indicated in patients with significantairway compression, and in young patients who have symptoms such as dyspnoea or dysphagia.296Option B: Median sternotomy approach is indicated in:•Primary mediastinal goiter•Malignant retrosternal goitre•Very large retrosternal goiter•Recurrence in the mediastinumFor a primary mediastinal goiter whose boundaries are completely within the chest, resection isoften achieved through median sternotomy or thoracotomy to ensure that the vessels supplyingthe tumor are properly ligated. Removing the tumor through a cervical approach can result inuncontrolled bleeding and is generally avoided.Option C: Blood supply to the retrosternal goiter is from the thyroid vessels (secondaryretrosternal goiter).

questions.question: Which of the following patients with thyroid swellings is least likely to require surgery?

options.A: A 22 year old woman with FNAC report of Bethesda category IV
options.B: A 66 year old man with a positive Pemberton's sign
options.C: A 58 year old man with an FNAC report of Thy2
options.D: A 16 year old girl with recurrence of thyroid cyst280

questions.explanation: FNAC report of Thy2 i.e. non-neoplastic is not an indication for surgery.Indications for surgical management of thyroid swellings include:•Neoplasia: FNAC positive Thy3-5 and clinical suspicionAge• Male sex• Hard texture• Fixity• Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy• Lymphadenopathy• Recurrent cyst• Toxic adenoma•Pressure symptoms• Cosmesis• Patient's wishes

questions.question: Pick from the following the usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy:

options.A: Rough handling of thyroid during surgery

questions.explanation: The usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy is inadequate patient preparation beforesurgery. Patient preparation pre-operatively involves ensuring a euthyroid state.Rough handling of the thyroid in thyroidectomy does not cause a thyroid storm. Though asignificant amount of thyroglobulin is stored in the acinar cells, they are inactive unless convertedto thyroxine (T3 and T4).297

questions.question: A patient with toxic adenoma is being prepared for surgery. Which of the followingstatements is wrong regarding this?

options.A: Iodine may be given pre-operatively with carbimazole
options.B: Beta blockers administered pre-operatively must be continued post operatively
options.C: Nadolol is given in a once daily regimen pre-operatively
options.D: The last dose of carbimazole must be given 24 hours before surgery

questions.explanation: The last dose of carbimazole may be given the evening before surgery.Toxic adenoma is a benign functioning thyroid tumour, which usually presents as a toxic solitarynodule. It is an autonomously functioning tumour that does not respond to TSH. Treatmentinvolves antithyroid drugs or radioactive iodine. This is followed by hemithyroidectomy as thesurrounding normal thyroid tissue regains normal function.Traditional preparation of a thyrotoxic patient aims to make the patient biochemically euthyroid.There are two methods of preparation that can be used:•⚫ Carbimazole 30-40 mg per day is the drug of choice. When euthyroid (after 8-12 weeks), the dosemay be reduced. Beta-blockers, if used preoperatively, must be given on the morning of surgeryand continued for a week post-op.•• Propranolol 40 mg TDS or a longer-acting nadolol 160 mg once daily may be given to achievebeta-blockade. It is important to continue treatment up to 7 days postoperatively.Iodine may be given with carbimazole or a beta-blocker 10 days before the operation. It producestransient remission and reduces thyroid vascularity.

questions.question: A 60-year-old man was posted for Hartley-Dunhill procedure. What is done in thisprocedure?

options.A: Total resection of lobes on one side, with partial resection on the other side
options.B: Partial resection of each lobe removing the bulk of the gland
options.C: Total resection of one lobe with partial resection of three lobes
options.D: Resection of two lobes with the removal of the isthmus

questions.explanation: Hartley Dunhill procedure involves total lobectomy on the affected side with sub total resection onthe less affected side.Indication: Asymmetrical multinodular goiters especially in older patients.

questions.question: You are performing thyroidectomy in a patient with thyroid neoplasia. Where willthe Kocher's incision?you make281
questions.explanation: The structures marked as "A" and "B" in the above image are thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilagerespectively. A Kocher transverse collar incision is typically 3 to 5 cm in length and is placedparallel to a natural skin crease 1 cm below the cricoid cartilage, which is marked as "B".Rose position is preferred for thyroid surgery. The patient is supine with a towel roll below theshoulder to enable neck extension of 30 degrees. The advantage is a blood-less field as there isdecreased venous congestion. However, there is an increased risk of air embolism.

questions.question: At which of the following points is the recurrent laryngeal nerve at the highest risk for injuryduring thyroid surgery?

options.A: At the level of Berry's ligament as it enters the larynx
options.B: In the tracheoesophageal groove as it forms one side of the Beahrs triangle
options.C: Under the tubercle of Zuckerkandl on the posterolateral portion of the gland
options.D: As the nerve loops around the aorta

questions.explanation: The point at which the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is at the highest risk for injury duringthyroid surgery is at its entry point into the larynx. This point is at the cricothyroid joint, at thelevel of Berry's ligament.298The recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve. On the left, it recurs over the arch ofaorta, and on the right over the subclavian artery.Beahrs' triangle or recurrent laryngeal nerve triangle is formed by:• Common carotid artery• Inferior thyroid arteries•Recurrent laryngeal nerveRecurrent laryngealnerve triangleCommoncarotid arteryCricoid cartilagePosterior suspensory(Berry ligament)Recurrent laryngealnerveNote: On the left side, the nerve has more distance in which to reach the transesophageal groove.Hence it runs in a medial plane. On the right, there is less distance and the nerve runs moreobliquely to reach the groove.

questions.question: In the post-op recovery room, a patient who had undergone a thyroidectomy suddenlyexperienced dyspnea with stridor. He was immediately sent back to the OT. What is the mostlikely cause for the patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Development of a hematoma post-thyroidectomy may lead to venous edema of the larynx.This can cause airway obstruction and respiratory distress. It is evacuated promptly at bedside orthrough surgical re-exploration.Complications of thyroidectomy:• Haemorrhage - most common complication overall• Nerve injury• External laryngeal nerve - hoarseness (more common)•⚫ Recurrent laryngeal nerve - hoarseness if unilateral, life-threatening aspiration and aphonia ifbilateral•Respiratory obstruction•• Laryngeal edema - most common cause of respiratory obstruction• Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy299• Laryngomalacia• Tension hematoma••Hypoparathyroidism - infarction of parathyroidsThyroid storm - inadequately prepared for surgery• Hypothyroidism• Recurrent thyrotoxicosis• Wound infection, stitch granuloma, keloidOption C: Venous embolism typically occurs after a prolonged period of immobilization.

questions.question: A patient who had undergone a retro-oesophagal goitre resection was found to have partialptosis and loss of hemifacial sweating. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner's syndrome.The cervical sympathetic trunk is at risk of injury in invasive thyroid cancers and retro-esophagealgoitres and may result in Horner's syndrome.300
